Tomb Raider: Legend has the sole honour of being a game that I've bought three times now, on three different platforms, and 100%'d three different times. I've yet to regret it.  Legend remains largely unchanged from it's original incarnation on the sixth generation, a fact which contributes to just what a fantastically optimized port it is. Honestly, stunning. 1 Ghz compatible? Other developers could take notes. Ran suberbly on my 1.8 Ghz toaster of a laptop, though for obvious reason it did mean having to forgo the visual changes added as the game was ported to seventh generation consoles - which range from relatively minor lighting adjustment to complete foliage overhauls. It's menu-toggled.  There were more than a few glitches - ranging from moderately amusing (floating rocks in Nepal) to moderately annoying (Lara refusing to grab ropes, plummeting to her death as she phases through them), and the game isn't lying when it says Partial Controller Support, but on the whole the experience was seamless.  Tomb Raider has you control Lara Croft in her quest for some contrived MacGuffin, spurred on by some event in the past and important because they say so, damn it. It's not the most compelling plot, and lacks the spectacle or involvement you'd get from an Indiana Jones or Librarian film.  That the antagonists; Rutland, Amanda, and Takamoto, are barely given any screentime to banter with Lara before being unceremoniously killed off doesn't help. Of more note are the support characters, Alistair and Zip, and Lara herself, all of whom give wonderfully entertaining performances. In one case their brilliant spurious dialogue alone manages to elevate an otherwise okay level to one of the best in the game.  Variety-wise, the levels are all incredibly distinct from one another, while the enemies are unfortunately not as much. The platforming mechanics are serviceable, and for the most part responsive, but incredibly underused; the best platforming level remains Croft Manor, a completely optional area. Likewise, the combat mechanics with the various kicks, bullet-time triggers, and grapples are all well and good, but almost completely unused in combat. It's a sad waste of potential.  Of note are the bosses, that take advantage of the mechanics to some degree instead of pretending that the game is something it's not. They're not particularly memorable, but none are less than on par.  It's a short game, incredibly short - if you haven't got a head for puzzles expect a good 7 hours, otherwise expect something closer to 5. Perhaps preferable to overstaying its welcome, but completely understaying it isn't fantastic either. The one billion unlockables they've managed to fit into the game help to counteract that - from concept art to outfits (hearkens to a day when they weren't just DLC, ey?) to model viewers and cheat codes, there's plenty there to play with.  Best puzzles are all saved for completely optional content - that is, grabbing the gold tokens. These legitimately involving puzzles (unless it's Nepal in which case it's hidden under some unremarkable ledge. Gorramn Nepal), which often require breaking previous puzzles, are all infinitely gratifying, and would be more so if the game didn't expect you to have a near-psychic amount of knowledge as to where they are before you even begin messing around to get to them.  Seriously, don't be ashamed to look up a hintbook or something to get even a vague idea of where they are. It's ridiculous.   With all this fairly good, there's some inexcusable bad. The QTEs are bad. The 'developer hints'; the frustratingly slow camera cuts to completely obvious platforming sections in completely linear levels that every sixth generation platformer had, are bad. The physics puzzles that expect you ignore how physics work - in one case assuming that a 90 pound girl like Lara can send deliriously heavy metal cubes rocketing into the sky with the help of a medieval see-saw - are bad.  But overall, Legend's saving grace is that it's extremely easy to play.   Everything from the writing, to the combat to the puzzles is designed solely for you to enjoy it and have fun. If you're up for a completely undemanding fun ride, to be completed with rocketing ease and satisfaction, then Tomb Raider: Legend is a game to look into.

Tomb Raider: Legend is the second of two games I bought last year in order to play through this seminal franchise of 90's era gaming before the 2013 'reboot' came along and destroyed the franchise forever. The first game - TR: Anniversary - was quite fun and enjoyable. TR:L however, was one of those experiences where I was fighting to stick around long enough to finish the game.  What TR:L does right is capture the essence of Lara Croft as a character and the platforming Tomb Raider does best. Lara in this game is perfectly portrayed as the confident and over-sexed adventurer we all know her as. Additionally, by this game's 2006 release, they had expanded the game locales from the eponymous tombs to skyscapers and military bases, to name two. Inserting Lara into these locales worked well, without too much juxtaposition of having an archaeologist run around modern sites.  The gameplay - particularly the platforming - is spot-on. It's a simple yet effective set of moves for Lara, you rarely feel that the controls are at fault when things turn to tears. This game is the classic example of sticking with what works, even in the face of more complex and more advanced modern gameplay. You grab stuff, you swing from things, and you jump around. Simple. It works.  But the problems with this game lie deep. Principally, I began to speculate as I got further into this game that it was developed independently by two different development teams: a platforming team and a combat team. The so-called platforming team did this game justice, as previously mentioned. This combat team however, is where things fall apart. Combat in Tomb Raider has never been my favorite thing. I still think that a pure platforming and environmental puzzle version of Tomb Raider would be the best game in the franchise. The combat really shows its inadequacies in the boss encounters. Just like in Anniversary, they are disjointed from the rest of the game. You will spend lots of time alone navigating a puzzle or whatever at your own pace, then all of a sudden a boss appears and the game throws arbitrary time constraints at you and asks the player to control Lara in ways that are not at all consistent or even to be used again within the rest of the game. In fact, the last boss was so infuriating I didn't even bother to try to beat it again after I was thoroughly trounced by it. By that point after almost 2 full games of this I had had enough. This disjointed back and forth between platforming and combat is in my opinion what makes these Tomb Raider games only good games and not great.  Secondly, the in-game radio between Lara and her intel people got completely out of hand. Lara would get frequent mission updates and story narrative from this two-way radio communication. I get that using that game mechanic is a great way produce a narrative in the game without having it be forced in through cut-scenes or whatever. Some games have even mastered it, think Cortana in Halo: Combat Evolved. But here in TR:L it was just too much, too frequently and in my opinion not all that important to the story. That sense of isolation in these expansive tombs is what was sorely missing in this title. Being able to solve a puzzle at your own pace with only your thoughts to guide you is the essence of good single-player puzzle platforming in my opinion.   So my two game Tomb Raider project ends here. TR:L wasn't horrible, but I would've been mad as hell if I paid fifty bucks for it on release in 2006. If you put a gun to my head and said I could only ever play one of these two titles - Anniversary or Legend - I would immediately say Anniversary is the way to go. Legend just has too many flaws to make the run through it worthwhile.

Another gripe is the nature of some of the puzzles. A good puzzle is where you know what needs to be achieved and need to go about finding a way to get there. Upon finishing TR anniversary for the second time around, I decided to finally play Legend. Turns out that Legend, Anniversary and Underworld form something of a trilogy or at least Legend and Underworld form a story and Anniversary gives a little more background story.   As for Legend, I enjoyed it more than Anniversary. There is more of a focus on action and 'doing stuff' rather than collecting ammo and finding secrets. The story is where it's at though, that's also a main focus in this game.   Graphically, for a game that's nearly 10 years old, it's nothing to write home about, 10 years ago though, it would have been pretty nice looking. They've enhanced it for PC, turn on the 'next gen' features and the game looks pretty ok, with some nice lighting, water and shadow effects, makes the game almost pretty decent to look at. There are the occasional annoying graphical glitches.   Sound, guns pack a punch, voice work isn't tacky but it can be pretty grating some times. The one liners from the cast are lame....sometimes you think to yourself ' I KNEW they were going to say that' .   Gameplay, puzzles are almost too easy, so easy you don't think of the most obvious solution because you're expecting something a bit harder from the TR series. The gunplay can be quite fun if you mix it up with more than just shooting stuff. Oh also, you don't have much of a choice in weapons.   One thing that carries over to Anniversary also is the annoying 'trajectory' jumping issue. You THINK you are lined up properly for a jump, there's no way you could possibly miss the target or jumping from one ledge to another, make the jump and fall to your death. Then once you attempt the same jump, all of the sudden it works. It's frustrating and annoying thinking to yourself ' BUT I JUST JUMPED DIRECTLY TOWARDS THE FREAKING LEDGE!!! ' Dark souls eat your heart out. Using either a keyboard and mouse or controller won't make a difference either.   You can bust through this in only 10-12 hours if you're only doing the story and not the rewards. All in all, it's a good addition to the series and I'd personally recommend playing this alongside Anniversary and Underworld seeing as the stories are related.

If you like your Tomb Raider, old school, with lots of falling to your death and shooting exotic wildlife in the face, this is for you. It's a bit short but it's not expensive. Plays nice with an Xbox360 controller. I recommend turing off the 'Next Gen' features. If you look in the discussion threads, you can find a patch but even then, it's too glitchy.  Brace yourself for inconsistent collisions. You can shoot through some fences, but not other, identical fences. The shooting was never Tomb Raider's strong point but for a 2006 game, it feels a little like a Dreamcast game like Dynamite Cop. That's not necessarity a bad thing.  The story is pretty lousy. I kind of zoned out, to be honest. There are some quicktime action sequences which are rather pointless. There are serious bugs all over the place so you may have to refer to a walkthrough here and there.  But even with all it's flaws, if feel just a little bit like Tomb Raider 2 and that's enough for me to recommend it.

Although it has some awesome locations,great,not overcomplicated puzzles and it's graphics really put on an astonishing atmosphere feeling,I cannot recommend this game for random players.It's camera (which causes 80% of deaths),tedious combat encounters and random crashes make it a quite mediocre game.However,if you enjoyed previous TR games like the sixth or fifth ones then pick it up.

Review by xTzharkz [Eric].  Tomb Raider: Legend. I loved it! After playing Tomb Raider IV this felt like heaven. Smooth gameplay nice voice acting, great story. Great game!  Okay lets go more into details now.  The story was built up nicely. Kept me intrested + the ending, made me want to know what next game is going to offer, if it is going to contiue the story. But I don't want to spoil anything so I leave it like that.   Gameplay was smooth, it did have few glitches but other movement worked great. I do not recommend to play on Hardest difficulty tho - which I did. In my head the harder the difficulty is the more fun I will have - due to challenges, but I ended up getting stuck, cuz I was not able to kill the enemies - little health packs - getting lot of damage. It was not that I was bad it but it was built up really poorly. Luckily after 2 hours of trying I manage to do it. So yeah better play either on easy or normal. It won't make the game any better when playing on hard. Trust me.  The puzzles in this game were not that hard. But I think the challenges this game offers pretty much fills the cap. What I mean are time trials, secrects. Also you can run around in house and look for secrets. How cool is that!?  Graphics were perfect! They had improved ones as well in the settings but I think the original ones were better. Lara Croft looked beautiful, sounded great and had awesome moves. Later on can change also outfits that will get unlocked by finishing the collections and trials. Biker outift... So sexy.  Anyway. I recommend the game! Go try it out. I think it was worth it.   xTzharkz [Eric]

Like Tomb Raider: Anniversary this is one is kinda hard to recommend but I'm only doing so because I found enough enjoyment and challenge out of the game to do so.  Controls are FAR better than the old school Tomb Raider games and movement feels much quicker. The core game play is largely still the same however - risky platforming, a few puzzles, and the dual pistols. Combat was fairly worse in my opinion however and for a tomb raider game there is A LOT of it.   The core issues with the combat comes from a few factors:  (1) Only one extra weapon to use than pistols, which you pick up from humans. Just use assault rifle ALL THE TIME. SMG isn't as strong or accurate and the shotguns range is pathetically short its useless in most situations. (2) 95% or so of the enemies are generic humans with guns. Running out of ammo for your secondary weapon is very uncommon and their AI is essentially to stand in one spot and shoot. (3) Uninspired boss fights. They are mostly shoot and dodge until a brief window opens up to use some gimmick such as a turret, shooting a platform, or swinging a grappling hook at a clearly pointed out object. Most of them are not hard at all and were not that fun.  Graphically it isn't anything spectacular but for its age it's fairly solid. There are FAR less bugs than Anniversary but there is one pain in the butt bug you will run into a couple of times that is more or less guaranteed to happen and it will crash your game. Just a heads up to get around this: reload the game, go to settings, turn off the next gen graphics option, play past the part that crashes, then re-enable the setting.  So between the crash bug and the often repetitive combat why do I recommend it? Because I still found it interesting enough for a play through. HOWEVER one caveat to that - I generally enjoy tomb raider games. Always did growing up and for the most part still do. If you're not a tomb raider fan and you are not planning on playing the sequel to this (Tomb Raider: Underworld), chances are you won't want to get this unless its on sale for cheap.

This is much more linear than the old TR games but it I found the story and gameplay enjoyable despite that. +The levels are varied, the puzzles make sense and Lara controls fluidly. You can also set the difficulty to easy if you don't like fighting enemies and want focus on the puzzle and story aspect. +There is a checkpoint system so you don't have to worry about saving a lot. -There are motorcycle sections that are cringe-worthy but only two of them so it doesn't kill the whole experience.  Fun game overall. Would recommend to anyone interested in the series or the basic premise.

Tomb Raider: Legend blows the 2013 reboot out of the water. It has actual puzzles, challenging platforming (in comparison), treasure-hunting which requires you to think, combat that's both somewhat fun and rare enough that it doesn't become a bore, and above all it stars the actual Lara Croft rather than some angst-filled crybaby. I had vague memories of playing TR: Legend at a friend's house as a child and liking it, but upon rediscovery it surpassed all my expectations. This is a good damn game.  The game does somewhat suffer from a pair of tedious vehicle sections and I found that some three or four areas were so bug-ridden as to be nearly unplayable. There's also apparently this bug that gives you a Fatal Error while starting the Kazakhstan chapter unless you turn off a bunch of stuff in the graphics menu. That I'm willing to overlook such normally unacceptable flaws only speaks to how much fun I had with this game. At the point of this writing, the game is only 2 eurodollars in the Steam Store for a solid 8-14 hours of fun. Go on goyim, buy buy!
